action.action-desc: Mr. Gottheimer (for himself, Mr. Moskowitz, Mr. Davis of North Carolina, and Mr. Tony Gonzales of Texas) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and Workforce

form.official-title: To amend the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to require silent alarms in elementary schools and secondary schools, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Alyssa’s Legacy Youth in Schools Safety Alert Act or the ALYSSA Act.

subsection.text: Section 1112(c) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 6312(c)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (5)(B)(ii)(III), by striking and at the end;
in paragraph (6), by striking and at the end;
in paragraph (7), by striking the period at the end and inserting ; and; and
by adding at the end the following:
ensure that each school served by the local educational agency is prepared to address a school security emergency, including through the use of panic alarms (as defined in section 8549D).

subsection.text: Subpart 2 of part F of title VIII of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7901 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

As a condition of receipt of funds under this Act, each local educational agency shall ensure that each elementary school and secondary school served by such local educational agency is equipped with at least one panic alarm for use in a school security emergency (including a non-fire evacuation, lockdown, or active shooter situation).

For purposes of this section and section 1112(c)(8), the term panic alarm means a silent security system signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a life-threatening or emergency situation requiring a response from law enforcement.
